resources.string: Press Back again to close the App.
Define a name for this profile.
Whoop! You haven\'t added any profiles yet.
Couldn\'t find any GPU related data
I couldn\'t find any relevant data :(
Caution: This will set your settings at boot.
It will inform you if your device had a sudden reboot.
Enable or disable the per-app profile service.
You are going to reset the tutorials.

If you want, you can become a beta tester. This means you will receive Aero Control updates earlier.
To become a beta tester, you need to fulfill two steps:


Join the Google+ Community


Apply for beta testing


Keep in mind that you can always leave the beta channel if you click the second link again.

Please notice that Google changed the way to check for the current foreground app for Lollipop(+). In order to make PerApp Service work on your device, you have to go into settings and enable usage statistics access for Aero Control. You can revoke this right at any point of time. If you are feeling ready, click continue.
Red - Light Holo with red accent
Light - Light Holo with blue accent
Dark - Light Holo with blue accent and black action bar

Hello. Thank you for using this App. My name is Alexander Christ (Blechd0se) and I have written this App for fun and in my spare time. Its also Open Source, so you can grab the Source Code and modify it as you want. If you want to, you can either donate to Quarx for his awesome rom or to me. The joy of living is in the giving.

This App is licensed under the Apache license. A copy of this can be downloaded here:
 http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0
 ShowCase Library by Alex Curran is licensed under the Apache 2.0 License.
 HoloGraph Library by Daniel Nadeau is licensed under the Apache 2.0 License.
It looks like your device is not rooted. This app won\'t work correctly without root. If you think this is a mistake, please let me know and send me an email!
Control Frequencies and Voltage in realtime!
This will set your favorite governor!
Set the governor Specific settings here.
Adjust the voltage of your cpu here
Dynamic FSync enables fsync only while the screen is off.
Change the read and write threshold for the entropy pool.
Enables or disabled the KSM deamon completely.
zCache uses CPU-time for a slightly better memory managment.
Choose the compression method for zCache.
Enable or Disable the writeback control here.
Enable or Disable the low memory option here. This might help on devices with 4.4+ (Kitkat).
Trim several parts of your system! This might take a while.
BusyBox is required for this operation!
Change parameters of the virtual machine.

Looks like your /data partition doesn\'t have the has_journal Feature enabled. Please reboot into recovery and run the following command via adb shell:
tune2fs -O has_journal /dev/block/mmcblk1p25

Looks like the kernel crashed. Be sure to check out 
/proc/last_kmsg 
and send this file to your favorite developer. Seriously, send it! 
 We apologize for any inconvenience!
This will enable the GPU Control driver. It handles overclocking/undervolting as well as some basic scheduling for the GPU.
This will set the maximum GPU Frequency. Default is 200 MHz.
May drain your battery a bit more than usual.
Wake your device with a doubletap gesture.
Tweak the governor parameters of your gpu.
This will save a copy of your current kernel.
Do you want to restore the backup from
Proceed with backup? This will backup your current kernel.
Are you sure you want to proceed?
This will reset your current usage statistics. Its like you just rebooted your phone.

Swipe from the left to the right to show the navigation drawer. The page you are currently looking at is the main overview panel. There is a small summary of some kernel settings. They are live, you don\'t have to refresh anything!
In order to maintain the device performance, you can trim several parts of your Operating System. This can take a while, especially when you stored lots of data.
Click this symbol to get the full access of governor control! You can tweak every parameter for every governor out there to gain performance.
You have found a secret feature! Be sure to tell nobody about this and if you have any troubles using it, don\'t worry. Its our little secret.
Just click on this little button and add a profile. All your current settings will be saved into this new Profile. If you have added multiple Profiles you can simply load them by clicking on them.
Want a certain profile only apply to certain apps? No problem, click to the right on the small icon and assign your profile to your favorite apps. Be sure to enable the service in the settings.

This panel will show you your current CPU Time consuming statistics. It displays how long your device has spend time in each CPU frequency. You might to want to check this later and see if your device performs as it should.
Click this symbol to get a simple filemanager. You can choose any file you wish and add your very own tunables. With the left icon you can delete those settings.
Color of your LED while charging
You haven\'t added any settings yet!
You have to enter a name.
Change the name of your profile.
This will completely reset your current profile. Just like if you freshly installed Aero Control.
You haven\'t changed any settings yet!
Per App Service not running, but you have associated apps to profiles!
I couldn\'t find anything to import.
No data is found yet, check back in a few minutes.
AppMonitor is disabled, please enable it in the settings to display data.
Click me and rate this app!
We are just about to get started. If you are feeling ready, just swipe from the right to the left. You can change all settings - which you will be changing in this assistant - later on.
Do you want to enable this service?

Choose your preferences for individual apps automatically. Therefore a service checks the foreground app every now and then and applies your desired profile automatically.\n This might save you some extra juice for your battery or give you a full performance boost on your favorite app.
With the little checkbox besides each settings you can set your values on boot individually. Just check it and your settings will be saved. This also defines your current profile values.
Do you want to enable tutorials?
Tutorials pop up during your usage of Aero Control. They might give you some insights. If you are an advanced user, it is unlikely that you need them.
Sending all data to the NSA...
Hang on a second, I know your data is somewhere...
We collected enough data, check them out in the AppMonitor section!
There is no information available about this item.
This tunable lets you adjust the maximum CPU frequency. Lowering this value can save you power at the cost of performance.
This tunable lets you adjust the minimum CPU frequency. Increasing this value can give a better performance at the cost of battery usage.
A tap on this element allows you to change various values of your hotplug driver. The hotplug driver decides when a CPU core should be on-/ or offline.

In this submenu you can change the voltage values of your CPU. This might increase your battery life or allows your CPU to run on higher frequencies. However, this can cause massive issues if overdone too much.
The CPU governor controls the scaling of the frequency of your CPU. A different governor can give a total different experience/batterylife.
Be careful with this option. You can overclock/underclock the listed frequency steps and set the correct voltage for it. Those values wont be applied to per-app profiles for your own safety.
The threshold for the average load of all currently onlined cpus to online the next core. If you lower this value, cores can get more easily online.

If enabled (1), only one core will stay active as soon as you turn off your screen. If you are getting strange audio quality while the screen is off, try switching it off via 0. This will let both cores stay active during suspend.
A debug flag intended for the developer. Nothing to do here!
The sampling rate of the hotplug driver. Lower this value and decisions will be made quicker in regards if a core should be onlined or not.
If enabled (1) it let\'s the hotplug driver react really quickly to short load spikes (100% CPU load) and onlines cpus accordingly.
To prevent core off-/onlining when they are near the threshold. This is the minimum online time in seconds for a core.
The threshold for a single core to online another one. For example; if core 1 is at 100% and the average load is above 60% core 3 will get online.
The minimum cpu frequency to start hotplug operations. If the current frequency is below this value, no hotplug operations will perform. Default is the maximum frequency.
Wait this long before raising speed above hispeed, by default a single timer interval.
Whether to align timer windows across all CPUs. When use_sched_load is true, this flag is ignored and windows will always be aligned.
The duration of the input boost.
Go to hispeed when CPU load at or above this value.
Hispeed to bump to from any smaller frequency when under heavy load.
The frequency the cpu will go to when a touch on the display is registered.

This is a flag that determines if waiting for various IO should increase the CPU utilization in bump up the cpu frequency. Setting this to 0 will mean the governor will increase the frequency less often.
Stay at the max freq for at least this value before dropping frequency again.
The minimum amount of time to spend at a frequency before we can ramp down.

At or above this value, the governor will ramp up the frequency. Lower values result in higher CPU speeds. An example would be \'85 1200000:80 1500000:95\'. This means the overall target load is 85, but if the frequency is higher than 1.2Ghz its 80. The same applies for 1.5Ghz but with 95.
The sample rate of the timer used to increase frequency
Max additional time to wait in idle, beyond timer_rate, at speeds above minimum before wakeup to reduce speed, or -1 if unnecessary.
Measured in uS (10^-6 seconds), this is how often you want the kernel to look at the CPU usage and to make decisions on what to do about the frequency.
Defines what the average CPU usage between the samplings of \'sampling_rate\' needs to be for the kernel to make a decision on whether it should increase the frequency.

This parameter takes a value of \'0\' or \'1\'. When set to \'0\' (its default), all processes are counted towards the \'cpu utilisation\' value. When set to \'1\', the processes that are run with a \'nice\' value will not count (and thus be ignored) in the overall usage calculation.

This parameter controls the rate at which the kernel makes a decision on when to decrease the frequency while running at top speed. When set to 1 (the default) decisions to reevaluate load are made at the same interval regardless of current clock speed. But when set to greater than 1 (e.g. 100) it acts as a multiplier for the scheduling interval for reevaluating load when the CPU is at its top speed due to high load.

This parameter takes a value between 0 to 1000. It defines the percentage (times 10) value of the target frequency that will be shaved off of the target. For example, when set to 100 -> 10%, when ondemand governor would have targeted 1000 MHz, it will target 1000 MHz - (10% of 1000 MHz) = 900 MHz instead. This is set to 0 (disabled) by default.
This tunable lets you change the maximum GPU frequency. Lowering this value can save you some juice at the cost of performance.
Lets you change the RGB (= red, green, blue) colors of your display to calibrate it.
Allows you to change the GPU governor. It handles the frequency scaling of your GPU and might have a big impact on the GPU performance.
Your GPU governor has some special tunables to fine-tune its behaviour. This is very similar to a CPU governor.
The kernel tries to readahead past requested data blocks and stores them in the cache to save potential disk I/O. The default value is 128KB. A higher value can increase app loadtime.
The fsync() call is intended to force a physical write of data from the buffer cache. Disabling this feature may give a performance boost, but at the cost of dataloss if your system crashes.

The entropy pool stores random numbers for various applications. Higher values for read/write can help in some cases, but can also increase the batterydrain. In general your pool should be always above 200 at any point of time.
fstrim is used on filesystems to discard ("trim") blocks which are not in use by the filesystem. This is very useful on flash-based storage devices.
This submenu lets you interact with the virtual machine of your device. Mostly there are memory related options.
The IO scheduler handles IO requests for a specific device to allow an efficient handling. Changing this value has a rather small impact on most android systems.
KSM or kernel samepage merging allows to deduplicate memory. Its a very useful feature on android and can save some RAM at the cost of CPU performance.
block_dump enables block I/O debugging when set to a nonzero value.

Contains the amount of dirty memory at which the background kernel flusher threads will start writeback.\n Note: dirty_background_bytes is the counterpart of dirty_background_ratio. Only one of them may be specified at a time. When one sysctl is written it is immediately taken into account to evaluate the dirty memory limits and the other appears as 0 when read.

Contains, as a percentage of total available memory that contains free pages and reclaimable pages, the number of pages at which the background kernel flusher threads will start writing out dirty data.

Contains the amount of dirty memory at which a process generating disk writes will itself start writeback.\nNote: the minimum value allowed for dirty_bytes is two pages (in bytes); any value lower than this limit will be ignored and the old configuration will be retained.

This tunable is used to define when dirty data is old enough to be eligible for writeout by the kernel flusher threads. It is expressed in 100\'ths of a second. Data which has been dirty in-memory for longer than this interval will be written out next time a flusher thread wakes up.

Contains, as a percentage of total available memory that contains free pages and reclaimable pages, the number of pages at which a process which is generating disk writes will itself start writing out dirty data.

The kernel flusher threads will periodically wake up and write \'old\' data out to disk. This tunable expresses the interval between those wakeups, in 100\'ths of a second.\nSetting this to zero disables periodic writeback altogether.

Writing to this will cause the kernel to drop clean caches, as well as reclaimable slab objects like dentries and inodes. Once dropped, their memory becomes free. (1 = free pagecache, 2 = free reclaimable slab objects, 3 = free slab objects and pagecache)

This parameter affects whether the kernel will compact memory or direct reclaim to satisfy a high-order allocation. Values tending towards 0 imply allocations would fail due to lack of memory, values towards 1000 imply failures are due to fragmentation and -1 implies that the allocation will succeed as long as watermarks are met.
This parameter tells the VM to keep extra free memory between the threshold where background reclaim (kswapd) kicks in, and the threshold where direct reclaim (by allocating processes) kicks in.

This defaults to 0 (false), meaning that the dirty_ratio and dirty_background_ratio ratios are calculated as a percentage of low memory only. This protects against excessive scanning in page reclaim, swapping and general VM distress.
laptop_mode is a knob that controls "laptop mode".
If non-zero, this sysctl disables the new 32-bit mmap layout - the kernel will use the legacy (2.4) layout for all processes.

For some specialised workloads on highmem machines it is dangerous for the kernel to allow process memory to be allocated from the "lowmem" zone. This is because that memory could then be pinned via the mlock() system call, or by unavailability of swapspace.

This file contains the maximum number of memory map areas a process may have. Memory map areas are used as a side-effect of calling malloc, directly by mmap and mprotect, and also when loading shared libraries.
This is used to force the Linux VM to keep a minimum number of kilobytes free.

Enables a system-wide task dump (excluding kernel threads) to be produced when the kernel performs an OOM-killing and includes such information as pid, uid, tgid, vm size, rss, nr_ptes, nr_pmds, swapents, oom_score_adj score, and name. This is helpful to determine why the OOM killer was invoked, to identify the rogue task that caused it, and to determine why the OOM killer chose the task it did to kill.
This enables or disables killing the OOM-triggering task in out-of-memory situations. The default value is 0.

This value contains a flag that enables memory overcommitment.
When this flag is 0, the kernel attempts to estimate the amount of free memory left when userspace requests more memory.
When this flag is 1, the kernel pretends there is always enough memory until it actually runs out.
When this flag is 2, the kernel uses a "never overcommit" policy that attempts to prevent any overcommit of memory.
When overcommit_memory is set to 2, the committed address space is not permitted to exceed swap plus this percentage of physical RAM.
This enables or disables panic on out-of-memory feature.

This is the fraction of pages at most (high mark pcp->high) in each zone that are allocated for each per cpu page list. The min value for this is 8. It means that we don\'t allow more than 1/8th of pages in each zone to be allocated in any single per_cpu_pagelist.
The time interval between which vm statistics are updated. The default is 1 second.

This control is used to define how aggressive the kernel will swap memory pages. Higher values will increase agressiveness, lower values decrease the amount of swap. A value of 0 instructs the kernel not to initiate swap until the amount of free and file-backed pages is less than the high water mark in a zone.
This percentage value controls the tendency of the kernel to reclaim the memory which is used for caching of directory and inode objects.
This tunable controls the vibration module of your phone. Usually a lower value means a softer vibration.
Choose the algorithm behind your network congestion control. Usually the default is \'cubic\' or \'reno\'.
The temperature threshold when your CPU starts to throttle to save it from overheating. Usually this value is in Â°C.
This value gives your speakers or your headphone a boost to get them a little louder.
This value let you increase or decrease the strength of the vibration module. Usually 100 is the max.
